awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research Initiation: Defining 21st Century Lifelong Learning Skills for Engineering Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
Lifelong learning is critical for the engineering field because of technological advancements, changing regulations, interpretation and synthesis of massive data, and a host of other factors.  Furthermore, the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology, professional licensure boards, and engineering education research have identified that lifelong learning needs to be promoted to better meet industry needs.  Currently, educators do not have a clear, and data proven, picture of what skills require additional study post-graduation, how practitioners engage in lifelong learning, or how student perceptions of lifelong learning may differ from practitioner's reality.  The goal of this research is to investigate practitioner experiences and perceptions of lifelong learning to determine the skills developed and methods of learning utilized.  The research will also investigate how those skills and methods change throughout career progression and how closely they match student perceptions of lifelong learning.  A better fundamental understanding of what and how practitioners study and develop skills as they progress through their career will inform the engineering education community about what learning abilities are required to be prepared for lifelong learning as professional engineers.
This study seeks to understand three research questions: 1) What skills are most developed by practitioners at different career positions, 2) How do practitioners find and consume information on the skills they want to develop, and 3) What perceptions do undergraduate students have about the skills they will need to develop throughout their career and how do they think they will develop those skills?  A research plan has been developed to investigate and answer these questions first by conducting qualitative analysis of semi-structured interviews of practicing engineers in the Pacific Northwest.  Interview recordings and transcripts will be analyzed using interpretative phenomenological analysis to obtain a rich understanding of practitioner perspectives of lifelong learning.  Then, the project will conduct quantitative analysis of lifelong learning survey results of practicing engineers and undergraduate students.  Lastly, researchers will compare the practitioner and student survey results to identify differences in perceptions about lifelong learning.  The outcomes of the mixed-methods study will quantify lifelong learning skills developed during engineering practice and their relationship to career position, which will increase our fundamental understanding about what skills practitioners study as they progress through their career.  Identifying gaps in knowledge and perceptions between student beliefs about lifelong learning and the realities of practice will provide insight to the engineering education field about what skills may be lacking or less developed and how future work could further improve engineer formation and preparation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Thirty years prior to ABET's inclusion of professional skills as critical student outcome for engineering programs, Abraham Maslow stated ?we must teach and train engineers not in the old and standard sense, but in a manner than enables them to confront novelty, improvise, and gain comfort in change.? He correctly predicted the need to educate engineers with the skills required to effectively engage in lifelong learning (LLL). To prepare students for LLL demands of the engineering field, engineering education research and practice has promoted training students in the importance of LLL early in engineer formation. However, even though student recognition of the importance of LLL has become an objective of engineering programs; a detailed description of what LLL entails, in terms of skills and methods, is not well understood. Educators do not have a clear, and data proven, picture of what skills require additional study post-graduation, what skills are most developed during a typical career trajectory, how practitioners engage in LLL, and where student perceptions of LLL may differ from practitioner?s reality of engaging in LLL. The goal of this project was to investigate practitioner LLL to determine the skills developed, methods of learning utilized, how those two factors relate to career position, and how closely student perceptions of LLL match practitioner realities. Without understanding the real-world lifelong learning of practitioners, it is difficult to effectively prepare students for the necessity LLL during early engineering formation.

The study accomplished this goal through both qualitative semi-structured interviews with practicing engineers and quantitative surveys distributed to practicing engineers and undergraduate students. This study resulted in a varied assortment of data from a population of professional engineers and undergraduate civil engineering students in the Pacific Northwest. The results of this study have advanced our understanding of the discipline specific skills required for civil engineering practice. It has validated prior research findings that stress the importance of communication and inter-personal skills, while also demonstrating that informal communication modes may be more frequently used, and of higher importance, than formal modes. This is especially important for engineering education, as engineering curriculums have done a lot in recent decades to improve writing and public speaking skills but have not done as much to systematically address informal communication skills, such as emails or impromptu discussions. Lastly, this project showed that student perceptions of practice are not that different from practitioners. This means that students are being well prepared with the understanding of the requirements of professional practice.

The intellectual merit of this study advanced our understanding of lifelong learning in civil engineering practice. First, this mixed-method study provided insights in specific skills that are learned during a civil engineering career. The findings provide the education community with a better fundamental understanding about what skills practitioners develop as they progress through their career and will assist engineering educators in crafting curriculum to best prepare students for all levels of professional practice. Additionally, this project provided insight into how practitioners engage in LLL. Practitioners mostly learn new skills through mentor relationships and on-the-job experience (i.e. trial-and-error), which both require the broad skills of self-regulated learning ability and learning metacognition.

This project fulfilled the broader impact of the NSF merit review criteria and WSU?s land-grant mission by taking fundamental research into professional practice to improve the engineering industry in the Pacific Northwest and provide data that can improve engineer formation in academia. The project provided a foundation for training and support for two graduate students in the development of research skills. Additionally, the project provided an engineering faculty member new to engineering education research the opportunity to grow as an engineering education researcher and strengthen their capabilities in qualitative and quantitative investigations. The PI is now more prepared to continue pursuing engineering education research and to contribute to the engineering education community. Results of this study have been disseminated to the research community through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations, both in-press and in-progress. Lastly, at a broader level, the results from this study could have continued long-term impact by providing the foundation to guide curriculum and pedagogical developments that better prepare students for the realities of learning new skills in entry-level engineering practice.
